name: 1613_E. Crazy Robot
description:
There is a grid, consisting of n rows and m columns. Each cell of the grid is either free or blocked. One of the free cells contains a lab. All the cells beyond the borders of the grid are also blocked.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab. It is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up". Each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command. Upon receiving a command, it will choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command and the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will do nothing.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell. That is, after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
prompt:
There is a grid, consisting of n rows and m columns, with each cell either free or blocked. All the cells beyond the borders of the grid are also blocked. The cells that are outside the grid boundaries are considered blocked, meaning that any movement towards them is restricted. One of the free cells contains a lab.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab, and it is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up", and each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command. It will, because upon receiving a command, choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command and the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will do nothing.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell, so that after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types:

  * '#' — the cell is blocked;

The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

The cells that are outside the grid boundaries are considered blocked, meaning that any movement towards them is restricted. One of the free cells contains a lab.

A crazy robot has escaped from this lab, and it is currently in some free cell of the grid. You can send one of the following commands to the robot: "move right", "move down", "move left" or "move up", and each command means moving to a neighbouring cell in the corresponding direction.

However, as the robot is crazy, it will do anything except following the command. It will, because upon receiving a command, choose a direction such that it differs from the one in command and the cell in that direction is not blocked. If there is such a direction, then it will move to a neighbouring cell in that direction. Otherwise, it will do nothing.

We want to get the robot to the lab to get it fixed. For each free cell, determine if the robot can be forced to reach the lab starting in this cell, so that after each step of the robot a command can be sent to a robot such that no matter what different directions the robot chooses, it will end up in a lab.

Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types:

Important Note: You must follow the input output format.  The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

completions:
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can guide the robot to the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid layout.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Count the number of free adjacent cells
                        free_adjacent_count = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_adjacent_count += 1

                        # If only one free adjacent cell, mark as reachable
                        if free_adjacent_count <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                            visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid layout.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Initialize BFS structures
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        
        # Directions for BFS traversal
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                # Check if the new position is within bounds and is a free cell
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count the number of free neighboring cells
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    
                    # If the free cell has only one free neighbor, it can be forced to reach the lab
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                        visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings for output
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
    
    # Call the function and print the results
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from collections import deque
from typing import List

def process_grid(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
    """Process the grid to determine which free cells can guide the robot to the lab.

    Args:
        n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
        m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
        grid (List[str]): The grid representation with free cells, blocked cells, and a lab.

    Returns:
        List[str]: The modified grid with '+' indicating cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.
    """
    # Directions for moving in the grid: right, down, left, up
    directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
    
    # Find the position of the lab
    lab_position = None
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(m):
            if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                lab_position = (i, j)
                break
        if lab_position:
            break
    
    # Initialize the queue for BFS and the visited set
    queue = deque([lab_position])
    visited = set([lab_position])
    
    # Convert grid to a list of lists for easier manipulation
    grid_list = [list(row) for row in grid]
    
    # Perform BFS from the lab
    while queue:
        x, y = queue.popleft()
        
        # Check all possible directions
        for dx, dy in directions:
            nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
            
            # Check if the new position is within bounds and is a free cell
            if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid_list[nx][ny] == '.':
                # Count the number of free neighboring cells
                free_neighbors = 0
                for ddx, ddy in directions:
                    nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                    if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid_list[nnx][nny] == '.':
                        free_neighbors += 1
                
                # If the free cell has only one free neighbor, it can be forced to reach the lab
                if free_neighbors <= 1:
                    grid_list[nx][ny] = '+'
                    queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))
    
    # Convert the list of lists back to a list of strings
    return [''.join(row) for row in grid_list]

def main():
    """Main function to handle input and output."""
    t = int(input())
    results = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        result = process_grid(n, m, grid)
        results.append(result)
    
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can reach the lab in each test case grid.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing:
            - n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            - m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            - grid (List[str]): The grid itself, with '.' for free cells, '#' for blocked cells, and 'L' for the lab.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: A list of grids with free cells replaced by '+' if the robot can be forced to reach the lab.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a mutable list of lists
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to mark reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                    free_directions = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_directions += 1

                    if free_directions <= 1:
                        if (nx, ny) not in reachable:
                            reachable.add((nx, ny))
                            queue.append((nx, ny))

        # Update the grid with reachable cells
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '.' and (i, j) in reachable:
                    grid[i][j] = '+'

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Find free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to mark reachable cells.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            grid (List[str]): The grid representation.

        Returns:
            List[str]: Modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        queue = deque()
        visited = set()
        lab_position = None

        # Find the lab position and initialize BFS
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    queue.append(lab_position)
                    visited.add(lab_position)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Perform BFS from the lab
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                    free_directions = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] != '#':
                            free_directions += 1
                    if free_directions <= 1:
                        grid[nx] = grid[nx][:ny] + '+' + grid[nx][ny+1:]
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        return grid

    result = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        modified_grid = bfs(n, m, grid)
        result.append(modified_grid)

    return result

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Call the function
result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

# Output interface
for grid in result:
    for row in grid:
        print(row)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can lead the robot to the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and the grid itself.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of processed grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find all reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell is a dead-end (only one free direction)
                        free_directions = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_directions += 1
                        if free_directions <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input().strip())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().strip().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Call the function
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)

    # Output interface
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        directions = [(-1, 0), (1, 0), (0, -1), (0, 1)]
        lab_position = None
        reachable = [[False] * m for _ in range(n)]
        
        # Find the lab position
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # BFS from the lab position
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        reachable[lab_position[0]][lab_position[1]] = True
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.' and not reachable[nx][ny]:
                    # Check if the cell is surrounded by blocked cells
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        reachable[nx][ny] = True
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
        
        # Construct the result grid
        result_grid = []
        for i in range(n):
            row = []
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == '.' and reachable[i][j]:
                    row.append('+')
                else:
                    row.append(grid[i][j])
            result_grid.append(''.join(row))
        
        return result_grid
    
    results = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        results.append(bfs(n, m, grid))
    
    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
    
    # Call the function and print the result
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for line in result:
            print(line)
from typing import List
## main.py
from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds the free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t: Number of test cases.
        test_cases: A list of tuples, each containing:
            - n: Number of rows in the grid.
            - m: Number of columns in the grid.
            - grid: A list of strings representing the grid.

    Returns:
        A list of grids with reachable free cells marked with '+'.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break

        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]

        # BFS to find reachable cells
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])

        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()

            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy

                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell is surrounded by blocked cells
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))

        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])

    return results

# Input interface
def main():
    t = int(input())
    test_cases = []
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, input().split())
        grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

    # Output interface
    results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    for result in results:
        for row in result:
            print(row)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Finds free cells from which the robot can be forced to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid layout.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: List of grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    results = []

    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Directions for BFS: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
        
        # Initialize BFS queue
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        
        # Visited set to keep track of reachable cells
        visited = set()
        visited.add(lab_position)
        
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            # Check all four possible directions
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                # Check if the new position is within bounds and is a free cell
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                    # Count free neighbors
                    free_neighbors = 0
                    for ddx, ddy in directions:
                        nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                        if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                            free_neighbors += 1
                    
                    # If the free cell has only one free neighbor, it can be forced to reach the lab
                    if free_neighbors <= 1:
                        grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                        visited.add((nx, ny))
                        queue.append((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        results.append([''.join(row) for row in grid])
    
    return results

# Input interface
t = int(input())
test_cases = []
for _ in range(t):
    n, m = map(int, input().split())
    grid = [input().strip() for _ in range(n)]
    test_cases.append((n, m, grid))

# Output interface
results = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
for result in results:
    for line in result:
        print(line)
from typing import List
## main.py

from typing import List, Tuple
from collections import deque

def find_reachable_cells(t: int, test_cases: List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]) -> List[List[str]]:
    """Determine which free cells can force the robot to reach the lab.

    Args:
        t (int): Number of test cases.
        test_cases (List[Tuple[int, int, List[str]]]): List of test cases, each containing grid dimensions and grid layout.

    Returns:
        List[List[str]]: Modified grids with reachable cells marked.
    """
    def bfs(n: int, m: int, grid: List[str]) -> List[str]:
        """Perform BFS to find all reachable cells from the lab.

        Args:
            n (int): Number of rows in the grid.
            m (int): Number of columns in the grid.
            grid (List[str]): The grid layout.

        Returns:
            List[str]: The modified grid with reachable cells marked.
        """
        # Directions for moving in the grid: right, down, left, up
        directions = [(0, 1), (1, 0), (0, -1), (-1, 0)]
        
        # Find the lab position
        lab_position = None
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(m):
                if grid[i][j] == 'L':
                    lab_position = (i, j)
                    break
            if lab_position:
                break
        
        # Initialize the queue for BFS and the visited set
        queue = deque([lab_position])
        visited = set([lab_position])
        
        # Convert grid to a list of lists for mutability
        grid = [list(row) for row in grid]
        
        # Perform BFS
        while queue:
            x, y = queue.popleft()
            
            for dx, dy in directions:
                nx, ny = x + dx, y + dy
                
                if 0 <= nx < n and 0 <= ny < m and (nx, ny) not in visited:
                    if grid[nx][ny] == '.':
                        # Check if the cell can be forced to reach the lab
                        free_neighbors = 0
                        for ddx, ddy in directions:
                            nnx, nny = nx + ddx, ny + ddy
                            if 0 <= nnx < n and 0 <= nny < m and grid[nnx][nny] == '.':
                                free_neighbors += 1
                        if free_neighbors <= 1:
                            grid[nx][ny] = '+'
                            queue.append((nx, ny))
                    visited.add((nx, ny))
        
        # Convert grid back to list of strings
        return [''.join(row) for row in grid]

    # Process each test case
    results = []
    for n, m, grid in test_cases:
        results.append(bfs(n, m, grid))
    
    return results

# Input interface
if __name__ == "__main__":
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    t = int(data[0])
    index = 1
    test_cases = []
    
    for _ in range(t):
        n, m = map(int, data[index].split())
        grid = data[index + 1:index + 1 + n]
        test_cases.append((n, m, grid))
        index += n + 1
    
    # Call the function and get the result
    result = find_reachable_cells(t, test_cases)
    
    # Output interface
    for grid in result:
        for row in grid:
            print(row)

requirement analysis:
The main requirement is to determine which free cells can guide the robot to the lab, considering the robot's unpredictable movement. The solution must efficiently handle large grids and provide clear output for each test case.

- Optimize the solution for large grid sizes
- Ensure the output format matches the requirements
- Handle edge cases where the robot cannot move
- Provide detailed documentation for the solution
We will use a breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to determine which free cells can guide the robot to the lab. The BFS will start from the lab cell and explore all reachable free cells, marking them as reachable. This approach ensures that we efficiently handle large grids by only exploring necessary paths. We will use a queue to manage the BFS and a set to track visited cells.

We will use a breadth-first search (BFS) algorithm to determine which free cells can force the robot to reach the lab. BFS is suitable for this problem as it efficiently explores all possible paths from the lab to other free cells, ensuring that we can handle large grids within the constraints. We will utilize a queue to manage the exploration of cells and a set to track visited cells to avoid redundant processing.
examples:
Input

The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of testcases.

The first line of each testcase contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n, m ≤ 10^6; n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6) — the number of rows and the number of columns in the grid.

The i-th of the next n lines provides a description of the i-th row of the grid. It consists of m elements of one of three types: 

  * '.' — the cell is free; 
  * '#' — the cell is blocked; 
  * 'L' — the cell contains a lab. 



The grid contains exactly one lab. The sum of n ⋅ m over all testcases doesn't exceed 10^6.

Output

For each testcase find the free cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Given the grid, replace the free cells (marked with a dot) with a plus sign ('+') for the cells that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Print the resulting grid.

Example

Input


4
3 3
...
.L.
...
4 5
#....
..##L
...#.
.....
1 1
L
1 9
....L..#.


Output


...
.L.
...
#++++
..##L
...#+
...++
L
++++L++#.

Note

In the first testcase there is no free cell that the robot can be forced to reach the lab from. Consider a corner cell. Given any direction, it will move to a neighbouring border grid that's not a corner. Now consider a non-corner free cell. No matter what direction you send to the robot, it can choose a different direction such that it ends up in a corner.

In the last testcase, you can keep sending the command that is opposite to the direction to the lab and the robot will have no choice other than move towards the lab.
